importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Hamas-led attack on Israel that killed Sergeant Major Tal Haimi, marking a pivotal event in the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict and the context for hostage-related developments.
The signing date of the US-proposed Gaza ceasefire deal, which established a framework for the return of hostages and set expectations for the transfer of deceased hostages within 72 hours.

The date of the identification and return of Sergeant Major Tal Haimi's body, signaling progress in the implementation of the ceasefire agreement and raising global attention on the humanitarian and diplomatic challenges of hostage recovery.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the signing of the US-brokered ceasefire to its most recent test, during which diplomatic and military tensions have emerged over the return of deceased hostages, especially due to Hamas's alleged inability to locate and return all bodies.

keyTakeAways: Sergeant Major Tal Haimi, a 41-year-old Israeli military officer, was killed on October 7, 2023, while defending a kibbutz during the Hamas-led attack.
Haimi's body was identified by Israeli forensics and returned to Israel on October 20, 2025, marking the 13th deceased Israeli hostage to be officially identified under the ceasefire agreement.

The ceasefire agreement requires Hamas to return all deceased hostages within the first 72 hours, but Israeli intelligence assesses that Hamas may not be able to locate and recover all remaining dead hostages due to war-related destruction in Gaza.
One of the bodies previously handed over by Hamas was not an Israeli hostage, suggesting possible misidentification rather than intentional wrongdoing.
The US has publicly threatened to 'eradicate' Hamas if it violates the ceasefire, with President Donald Trump warning of military action if violence continues.
Senior US officials, including Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, held meetings with Israeli military leaders to discuss ceasefire compliance and hostage recovery.
The Hostages and Missing Families Forum expressed condolences to Haimi’s family, highlighting the emotional toll of prolonged uncertainty and the significance of the return of a deceased hostage.
Israel continues to demand that Hamas take necessary steps to return all deceased hostages, underscoring the humanitarian and political urgency of the issue.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, Israeli authorities identified the body of Sergeant Major Tal Haimi, a 41-year-old Israeli military officer killed during the October 7, 2023 Hamas attack, as part of the ongoing process of returning deceased hostages under a US-brokered ceasefire agreement. Haimi was the 13th such individual to be identified since the ceasefire was signed on October 9, 2025. Despite the agreement requiring Hamas to return all deceased hostages within 72 hours, Israeli intelligence and military officials have expressed concerns about Hamas’s ability to locate and recover all bodies due to extensive war damage in Gaza. The return of Haimi's body, after being retrieved by the Red Cross and transferred to Israeli forces, underscores both the personal and political significance of hostage recovery. The issue has drawn international attention, with US President Donald Trump threatening to 'eradicate' Hamas if it violates the ceasefire, and US officials, including Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, holding direct meetings with Israeli military leaders to ensure compliance. Meanwhile, the Hostages and Missing Families Forum has expressed deep condolences to Haimi’s family, highlighting the emotional toll of prolonged uncertainty and the importance of proper recognition and burial of the deceased.
title: Israel Identifies Body of Deceased Hostage as Sergeant Major Tal Haimi
